chunk: The deductible is the amount you must pay out-of-pocket each year before your insurance plan begins to cover most medical services.
Preventive care services such as annual checkups, immunizations, and screenings are typically covered at no cost to the patient.
Emergency services are generally covered regardless of network status. Many plans waive the deductible for emergency room visits.
Urgent care visits usually require a copayment, which is a fixed fee paid at the time of the visit, separate from the deductible.
A copayment is a flat fee you pay for certain services, such as specialist visits, prescriptions, or urgent care visits.
Coinsurance is the percentage of costs you must pay after meeting your deductible. For example, you may be responsible for 20% while the plan covers 80%.
The out-of-pocket maximum is the most you will pay for covered services in a plan year. After you reach it, the plan pays 100% of covered services.
Prescription drugs may require prior authorization. This means your doctor must get approval from your insurance company before the medication will be covered.
Some plans require a referral from your primary care physician before you can see a specialist. Without a referral, the visit may not be covered.
In-network providers are doctors or facilities that have agreed to lower rates with your insurance company. Using them usually lowers your costs.
Out-of-network providers have not negotiated rates with your insurance plan and may result in higher charges or no coverage for certain services.
Some plans include separate deductibles for prescription drugs, meaning you must meet a specific amount before drug coverage begins.
Telehealth visits are often covered similarly to in-person visits, but some plans waive copays for virtual consultations.
Laboratory tests such as blood work might be subject to coinsurance after the deductible is met, depending on your plan details.
Imaging services such as MRIs or CT scans often require prior authorization and may involve coinsurance after deductible payment.
Physical therapy services may require a referral and may also be limited to a certain number of sessions per year according to the plan.
Mental health services are generally covered similarly to medical services and may include copays or coinsurance depending on network status.
Maternity care is considered essential health coverage and includes prenatal visits, labor, delivery, and postnatal checkups.
Some preventive medications, such as certain vaccines or birth control pills, may be covered with no cost-sharing under many insurance plans.
Certain high-cost specialty drugs may require step therapy, meaning you must try lower-cost alternatives before the plan approves the more expensive option.
